PRICE 5 CENTS
GENIUS OF SIDNEY LANIER
PRAISED AT HOPKINS
COMMEMORATION
Eighty-Fourth Anniversary Of Poet's
Birth Celebrated At Peabody
Conservatory Of Music
The poetical, musical, and scientific genius of Sidney Lanier,
the only poet to whom Johns Hopkins University can justly lay
claim as its own, was extolled at
the Sidney Lanier Commemoration, held at the Peabody Conservatory on February 4.
Dr. Oliver Huckel made the
principal address of the evening
on the subject, "Genius of the
Modern in Lanier." He praised
Lanier's rollicking good humor,
his fine character, his remarkable
accomplishments. As a poet, Dr.
Huckel declared him to be high
up in the list of the dozen foremost American poets, and unharmed by comparison with such
English masters as Shakespeare,
Milton, Tennyson, and Browning.
"Lanier is recognized today as a
great poet and a great soul," Dr.
Huckel said.
Traces Life
In addition to extolling Lanier's
various talents, Dr. Huckel traced
his life from the day he was born,
February 3, 1842, at Macon, Georgia, until his death in Baltimore
on September 7, 1881. Lanier's
sojourn at Oglethorpe College,
where he came under the influence
of a professor named James Woodrow; his desire to go to Germany
for research work'; his going to
war, and imprisonment, re'sponsibilities, and illness resulting from
the war, were duly dwelt upon.
Other speakers on the program
were Dr. John C. French, who
took the place of Miss Lizette
Woodworth Reese, unable to attend the commemoration; Dr. L.
Wardlaw Miles, Mrs. Arthur B.
Kinsolving, and Dr. Frank J.
Goodnow. Dr. French read Miss
Reese's paper on "The Spirituality of Lanier," while Dr. Miles
gave a rather disappointing reading of excerpts from "The Symphony" and "Ode to Beethoven."
Mrs. Kinsolving read a tribute to
Lanier as a musician made by Asger Hamerik, Director of the Peabody Conservatory, 1871-1898.
"Lanier and the University" was
the subject of Dr. Goodnow's closing address.
Hopkins Orchestra Plays
Between the addresses the
Johns Hopkins Orchestra, conducted by Mr. Charles H. Bochau,
rendered selections or accompaChief
nied various soloists.
among the latter were Mr. William G. Horn, who sang Lanier's
"Ballad of Trees and the Master"
and "Evening Song," and Mr.
Frederick Gottlieb, who played
two of Lanier's favorite melodies
on his flute. The exercise closed
with a rendition of Gustav
Strube's "Lanier Symphony."
The Sidney Lanier Memorial
Committee, of which Dr. John C.
French is chairman, not only arranged all matters pertaining to
the celebration, but is even now
considering the creation at Johns
Hopkins University of some such
permanent memorial to the poet
as shall worthily commemorate

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 9, 1926.

UNLIMITED CUTS
Up°n. casual inspection of the lists of grades posted on the
Various bulletin boards about the campus, we are very strongly
impressed by the frequency with which the words "grade withheld on account' of absences" appear. Truly it seems that
Johns Hopkins methods are not far.aboAw.those of the average
high or preparatory school with regard to *fills matter of socalled discipline. For if, a student, in spite of non-attendance
upon classes, is able to make a passing grade, should he not be
given credit for the knowledge which he has managed to acquire
without the assistance of the instructor?
In nearly every case there should be no reason for this
restriction of cuts, for the required attendance upon classes.
Every student knows that nine-tenths- of all lectures are merely
a _rehash of matters which are treated fully in the texts. And
the Men who do contribute something new to the course in
Their lectures have surprisingly few absences to contend with.
Johns Hopkins has always been an exponent of,free action
and speech; within the limits of decency, students have been
allowed to. do almost what they pleased. Other universities
have decided to allow unlimited cuts; Harvard and Yale have
recently adopted the plan for upperclassmen. We do not advocate freedom from restrictions for the first two classes, but
we feel that. upperclassmen should be allowed this additional
freedom: It would be in accord with the policy of. advanc6d
work and 'freedom of action to which the university stands
committed.

AN EXCELLENT SUGGESTION
At the end of his address, made at the recent Sidney Lanier
memorial exercises, Dr. Oliver Huckle suggested that the Johns
Hopkins University erect a substantial and material shrine
to the poet. A room where all Lanier memorabilia could be
gathered, where relics of the man and the poet could be placed,
where all available manuscripts and editions of the poet's work
could be assembled; this was, in the main, Dr. Huckle's idea.
This is an excellent suggestion. Lanier was closely connected with Johns Hopkins as a lecturer and teacher. He is
the only poet of any rank who has had any close contact with
this University. Yet, save for the Lanier ivy that twines about
the bricks of Gilman Hall, except for a bust hidden in an
obscure and dusty corner of a forgotten corridor, there is
nothing at Homewood, in material form, that brings the poet
to mind. How pleasant it would be to have a place where one
could see the desk at which Lanier wrote, could see the flute
which brought forth "those golden notes," could easily have
access to his complete works and manuscripts.
The recently formed Lanier Memorial Committee has for
its object the establishing of a suitable memorial to the poet
at Hopkins. Such suggestions as that of Dr. Huckle should
receive serious consideration.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 9, 1926.

“Y" FELLOWSHIP
DINNER TONIGHT
The Rev. J. W. G. Fast
will be the principal speaker
at the Y. M. C. A. Fellowship Dinner to be held at the
Friends' Meeting House tonight at six o'clock. A large
attendance is expected, in
view of the fact that many
of those who attended last
year's dinner have for some
time been clamoring for a
repetition of that very successful affair.
This is the first Fellowship
Dinner of the year 1925-26.
Those who wish to make
reservations may still do so
this afternoon. - Tickets are
on sale at the i`Y" office for
50 cents each.

Hair Catches Fire
After Explosion
An explosion on January twenty-ninth in an ether -extracting
machine at• the Johns Hopkins
School of Hygiene and Public
Health endangered the life of
Miss Lois Witham, the experimenter in the laboratory at the
time, when it set fire to her hair.
One of the other women experimenters extinguished the flames
by throwing a coat over Miss
Witham's head. Later, Dr. McCollum completed the quenching
by subjecting the young lady's
head to a stream of water from
one of the showers.

PRICE 5 CENTS
GENIUS OF SIDNEY LANIER
PRAISED AT HOPKINS
COMMEMORATION
Eighty-Fourth Anniversary Of Poet's
Birth Celebrated At Peabody
Conservatory Of Music
The poetical, musical, and scientific genius of Sidney Lanier,
the only poet to whom Johns Hopkins University can justly lay
claim as its own, was extolled at
the Sidney Lanier Commemoration, held at the Peabody Conservatory on February 4.
Dr. Oliver Huckel made the
principal address of the evening
on the subject, "Genius of the
Modern in Lanier." He praised
Lanier's rollicking good humor,
his fine character, his remarkable
accomplishments. As a poet, Dr.
Huckel declared him to be high
up in the list of the dozen foremost American poets, and unharmed by comparison with such
English masters as Shakespeare,
Milton, Tennyson, and Browning.
"Lanier is recognized today as a
great poet and a great soul," Dr.
Huckel said.
Traces Life
In addition to extolling Lanier's
various talents, Dr. Huckel traced
his life from the day he was born,
February 3, 1842, at Macon, Georgia, until his death in Baltimore
on September 7, 1881. Lanier's
sojourn at Oglethorpe College,
where he came under the influence
of a professor named James Woodrow; his desire to go to Germany
for research work'; his going to
war, and imprisonment, re'sponsibilities, and illness resulting from
the war, were duly dwelt upon.
Other speakers on the program
were Dr. John C. French, who
took the place of Miss Lizette
Woodworth Reese, unable to attend the commemoration; Dr. L.
Wardlaw Miles, Mrs. Arthur B.
Kinsolving, and Dr. Frank J.
Goodnow. Dr. French read Miss
Reese's paper on "The Spirituality of Lanier," while Dr. Miles
gave a rather disappointing reading of excerpts from "The Symphony" and "Ode to Beethoven."
Mrs. Kinsolving read a tribute to
Lanier as a musician made by Asger Hamerik, Director of the Peabody Conservatory, 1871-1898.
"Lanier and the University" was
the subject of Dr. Goodnow's closing address.
Hopkins Orchestra Plays
Between the addresses the
Johns Hopkins Orchestra, conducted by Mr. Charles H. Bochau,
rendered selections or accompaChief
nied various soloists.
among the latter were Mr. William G. Horn, who sang Lanier's
"Ballad of Trees and the Master"
and "Evening Song," and Mr.
Frederick Gottlieb, who played
two of Lanier's favorite melodies
on his flute. The exercise closed
with a rendition of Gustav
Strube's "Lanier Symphony."
The Sidney Lanier Memorial
Committee, of which Dr. John C.
French is chairman, not only arranged all matters pertaining to
the celebration, but is even now
considering the creation at Johns
Hopkins University of some such
permanent memorial to the poet
as shall worthily commemorate

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 9, 1926.

UNLIMITED CUTS
Up°n. casual inspection of the lists of grades posted on the
Various bulletin boards about the campus, we are very strongly
impressed by the frequency with which the words "grade withheld on account' of absences" appear. Truly it seems that
Johns Hopkins methods are not far.aboAw.those of the average
high or preparatory school with regard to *fills matter of socalled discipline. For if, a student, in spite of non-attendance
upon classes, is able to make a passing grade, should he not be
given credit for the knowledge which he has managed to acquire
without the assistance of the instructor?
In nearly every case there should be no reason for this
restriction of cuts, for the required attendance upon classes.
Every student knows that nine-tenths- of all lectures are merely
a _rehash of matters which are treated fully in the texts. And
the Men who do contribute something new to the course in
Their lectures have surprisingly few absences to contend with.
Johns Hopkins has always been an exponent of,free action
and speech; within the limits of decency, students have been
allowed to. do almost what they pleased. Other universities
have decided to allow unlimited cuts; Harvard and Yale have
recently adopted the plan for upperclassmen. We do not advocate freedom from restrictions for the first two classes, but
we feel that. upperclassmen should be allowed this additional
freedom: It would be in accord with the policy of. advanc6d
work and 'freedom of action to which the university stands
committed.

AN EXCELLENT SUGGESTION
At the end of his address, made at the recent Sidney Lanier
memorial exercises, Dr. Oliver Huckle suggested that the Johns
Hopkins University erect a substantial and material shrine
to the poet. A room where all Lanier memorabilia could be
gathered, where relics of the man and the poet could be placed,
where all available manuscripts and editions of the poet's work
could be assembled; this was, in the main, Dr. Huckle's idea.
This is an excellent suggestion. Lanier was closely connected with Johns Hopkins as a lecturer and teacher. He is
the only poet of any rank who has had any close contact with
this University. Yet, save for the Lanier ivy that twines about
the bricks of Gilman Hall, except for a bust hidden in an
obscure and dusty corner of a forgotten corridor, there is
nothing at Homewood, in material form, that brings the poet
to mind. How pleasant it would be to have a place where one
could see the desk at which Lanier wrote, could see the flute
which brought forth "those golden notes," could easily have
access to his complete works and manuscripts.
The recently formed Lanier Memorial Committee has for
its object the establishing of a suitable memorial to the poet
at Hopkins. Such suggestions as that of Dr. Huckle should
receive serious consideration.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 9, 1926.

“Y" FELLOWSHIP
DINNER TONIGHT
The Rev. J. W. G. Fast
will be the principal speaker
at the Y. M. C. A. Fellowship Dinner to be held at the
Friends' Meeting House tonight at six o'clock. A large
attendance is expected, in
view of the fact that many
of those who attended last
year's dinner have for some
time been clamoring for a
repetition of that very successful affair.
This is the first Fellowship
Dinner of the year 1925-26.
Those who wish to make
reservations may still do so
this afternoon. - Tickets are
on sale at the i`Y" office for
50 cents each.

Hair Catches Fire
After Explosion
An explosion on January twenty-ninth in an ether -extracting
machine at• the Johns Hopkins
School of Hygiene and Public
Health endangered the life of
Miss Lois Witham, the experimenter in the laboratory at the
time, when it set fire to her hair.
One of the other women experimenters extinguished the flames
by throwing a coat over Miss
Witham's head. Later, Dr. McCollum completed the quenching
by subjecting the young lady's
head to a stream of water from
one of the showers.

DON'T FORGET!

SIX ACRES DONATED •
FOR MUSEUM SITE

CLOTHIERS

Trustees Give City Choice of Land
Adjoining Wyman Park

Today

In consequence of the Baltimore
City Board of Estimates' approval
of a Johns Hopkins-Wyman Park
site for the proposed Art Museum, the Johns Hopkins Board
of Trustees voted, on January 30,
to donate- 16 the city six acres of
land adjoining Wyman Park.
The Trustees' resolution stipulated that the six acres should be
selected by the Chief of the Bureau of Plans and Survey from a
tract of ,about'even acres, bounded on the north by a line running
due west from the old Wyman
Park gatehouse, above Thirtyfirst St., and on the west by a line
bisecting Oak St., extended. Also
that unless a building is begun in
three years, or in case the property should even be abandoned, it
will revert to the University.

TAG DAY ABOLISHED
(Continued from p. 1, col. 3)
It is expected that every Hopkins

man will rise to the occasion.
Announcement of the committee's change in the policy of acquirement of funds will without
doubt meet with approval on the
campus. Those who have noticed
the absence of tag days this college -year are undoubtedly pleased
that the spring months will not
be marred by 'an elongated series
of subscribing periods.
In its present move, the 1926
June Week Committee is continuing its policy of disregarding the
practice of former years. Other
vivid _changes in June Week policy, as announced several months
ago, have been the reduction in
price, the use of local instead of
out-of-town musicians, and the determination to make June Week
an all-Hopkins affair.
